s.text: More surprising yet, Internet proselytizing is often led by actual smart people--people like Esther Dyson.
More surprising yet, Internet proselytizing is often led by actual smart people--people like Esther Dyson.
More surprising yet, Internet proselytizing is often led by actual smart people--people like Esther Dyson.
It vanishes as soon as the subject turns to the Internet and its alleged power to transform our lives.
It vanishes as soon as the subject turns to the Internet and its alleged power to transform our lives.
"It may not be nice to say it," she writes at one point, "but people are not all always nice, and therefore a little social pressure can be a good thing."
"It may not be nice to say it," she writes at one point, "but people are not all always nice, and therefore a little social pressure can be a good thing."
It seems fair to say that, in part as a result of our experience with television, we tend to shy away from making grandiose claims for new technologies anymore.
"I live on the Net," writes Dyson--and it shows.

Her profile is high enough that the publisher felt justified in putting her face on the cover of her new book, which is titled Release 2.0 . (Dyson says that the paperback edition, when it comes out, will be called Release 2.1 . Cute.)
The larger problem is that the Internet is simply not going to make us nicer people--nor are we going to become nicer just because we want to see the Internet reach its full potential.
All that e-mailing she does appears to have caused her to forget how to write more than four consecutive paragraphs at a time.

All that e-mailing she does appears to have caused her to forget how to write more than four consecutive paragraphs at a time.
It seems fair to say that, in part as a result of our experience with television, we tend to shy away from making grandiose claims for new technologies anymore.
It seems fair to say that, in part as a result of our experience with television, we tend to shy away from making grandiose claims for new technologies anymore.

Her profile is high enough that the publisher felt justified in putting her face on the cover of her new book, which is titled Release 2.0 . (Dyson says that the paperback edition, when it comes out, will be called Release 2.1 . Cute.)
The notion is ludicrous on the face of it.
Nice books, for instance, are usually bland books--as this one is.
All that e-mailing she does appears to have caused her to forget how to write more than four consecutive paragraphs at a time.
